titleStmt.title: Two most srange [sic] and notable examples, shewed at Lyshborne the 26. day of Ianuarie now last past The one by striking dumme two of the cheefe of the holy-house, as they were pronouncing the sentence of death against two English Mariners, vnto whom they had offered great promotion, to haue them to serue against the King of France, and their owne countrie. The other within sixe dayes then next following, by burning two ships of corne in the harboure there, which was brought out of France to releeue the King his enimies: an example most wonderfull. ... Affirmed for truth by those men vnder named, of honest reputation, being present at the dooing thereof, the one maister of the ship called the Fortune: the other maister of the Flying Harte. Hance Hogenberge, & Adrian van How. Signed for truthe in the presence of those here vnderwritten. Henry Roberts. Water Mantle. Iohn Nshe. Robert Ihones.

titleStmt.title: Two most srange [sic] and notable examples, shewed at Lyshborne the 26. day of Ianuarie now last past The one by striking dumme two of the cheefe of the holy-house, as they were pronouncing the sentence of death against two English Mariners, vnto whom they had offered great promotion, to haue them to serue against the King of France, and their owne countrie. The other within sixe dayes then next following, by burning two ships of corne in the harboure there, which was brought out of France to releeue the King his enimies: an example most wonderfull. ... Affirmed for truth by those men vnder named, of honest reputation, being present at the dooing thereof, the one maister of the ship called the Fortune: the other maister of the Flying Harte. Hance Hogenberge, & Adrian van How. Signed for truthe in the presence of those here vnderwritten. Henry Roberts. Water Mantle. Iohn Nshe. Robert Ihones.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed [by A. Jeffes] for William Barley, and are to be solde at his shop in Newgate Market,

notesStmt.note: Running title reads: A worthy example of burning two ships of corne.
Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: TWO MOST SRANGE AND notable examples, shewed at Lyshborne the 26. day of Ianuarie now la≈øt pa≈øt.

THE ONE BY STRIKING DVMME two of the cheefe of the Holy-hou≈øe, as they were pronouncing the ≈øentence of death again≈øt two Engli≈øh Marriners, vnto whom they had offered great promotions, to haue them to ≈øerue again≈øt the King of France, and their owne Countrie.
The other within ≈øixe dayes then next following, by burning two Ships of Corne in the Harboure there, which was brought out of France to releeue the King his enimies: An example mo≈øt wonderfull.
A notable warning to ≈øuch Engli≈øh Marchants, which for their owne benefit, by carrying our victuals away, impoueri≈øh our Countrey, and ≈øtrengthen the enemies of God and our Prince.
Affirmed for truth by tho≈øe men vnder named, of honest reputation, being pre≈øent at the dooing thereof, the one Mai≈øter of the Ship called the Fortune: the other Maister of the Flying Harte.
Hance Hogenberge, & Adrian van How.
Signed for truthe in the pre≈øence of tho≈øe here vnderwritten.
LONDON Printed for William Barley, and are to be ≈øolde at his ≈øhop in Newgate Market. ANNO. 1591.

div.head: A worthie example of burning two Ships of Corne brought for the releefe of the enemie vnto Li≈øhborne.
div.p:
IN the Moneth of Augu≈øt, 1586. There was taken by the Spaniards a tall Ship called the Barke rowe, now belonging vnto the Towne of Newca≈øtell vpon Tine, the Mai≈øter of which Ship at that time was one Iohn Harri≈øon, borne in Cornwall, and foure others with him, which becau≈øe they were found to be men of reputation, and of good experience in their Arte, were had in more regarde then the re≈øt. And whereas the company were all condemned to the Galleyes, where ≈øome of them yet ≈øerue. They were committed vnto the cu≈øtody of a Caualier, who had charge to v≈øe them with great curte≈øie. One whole yeare remained they in the keeping of this their fir≈øt Hoa≈øte, with very great entertainment, where they were often vi≈øited with Friers and other religious per≈øons, which very earne≈øtly laboured to drawe them both from God, and their allegiance to their Prince, which howe earne≈øt ≈øo euer they were ≈øolicited, it plea≈øed God to ≈øtrengthen them, ≈øo that their hearts were hardened again≈øt their religion and them, who ≈øcorned to how to any Idols, knowing that they bee but ≈øtones, and the
workes of mens hands, and therefore vtterly refu≈øed to giue the glorie of the Omnipotent God, to ≈øuch tra≈øh as they honoured. The≈øe ≈øhauelings, when as they ≈øawe no hope to winne tho≈øe ≈øoules as they terme it, conferring together touching their ob≈øtinacie, thought to prooue if ≈øome ha≈øher v≈øage might make them yeelde: wherefore the Cardinall of Li≈øhborne, Viceroye to the King of Spayne, at who≈øe commaund they were: being enformed by ≈øuch as he ≈øent, howe they aun≈øwered to ≈øuch demaundes which were required of them, commaunded that the ≈øayde Iohn Harri≈øon, and his foure companions, ≈øhould all bee ommitted vnto the Inqui≈øition or Holy hou≈øe, and there to abide ≈øuch puni≈øhment as theyr manner is to laye vpon the Children of GOD, which was pre≈øently doone as he gaue in charge, and they all ≈øeuerally impri≈øoned, in ≈øuch loath≈øome places as it would haue pittied a man to haue ≈øeene theyr e≈øtate, during the time of their durance there.

Twi≈øe euerye weeke would they ≈øende vnto them, villaines di≈øgui≈øed in the counterfaite attire of a Deuill, which cruelly, like him that he repre≈øented, would ≈øcourge them with whips of Wyer, ≈øo that theyr fle≈øhe was mo≈øt greeuou≈ølye torne with tho≈øe tormentors, liuing with no other vyandes, but onely with boiled Barlye, and faire water. of which they ≈øcantly had theyr bellyes full. Thus by Gods fauour, who ≈øtrengthneth his ≈øeruants, continued tho≈øe our Countreymen ≈øtedfa≈øt in the faith of Chri≈øt, refu≈øing all the vanities of the worlde, to beare the Cro≈ø≈øe of their Redeemer (Chri≈øt Ie≈øus.)

Two yeares ≈øpente they in the≈øe extremities, in which time two of them by Gods vi≈øitation dyed, whom the≈øe Caniballes would not allowe Chri≈øtian buriall vnto, for that they dyed not in their faith.

Well, their great Fleete beeing prepared for England, men of ≈økyll for the Coa≈øt was greatlye wantnig, ≈øo that there was great meanes made for all men of what nation ≈øo
euer that would take charge, Among≈øt which there was ≈øent for, this Iohn Harri≈øon, and his two con≈øorts Peter Bryan his Mate, a verye good Marriner, and William Mathewes, the Gunner, braue men, and of ≈øtoute Courage.

Tho≈øe men being brought vnto the pre≈øence of the Cardinall, humbling them≈øelues as to the Kinges Viceroye one their knee‚ñ™ The Cardinall came to take them vp, and ble≈ø≈øed them with his hand, making on their heads the ≈øigne of the Holy Cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øpeaking two or three wordes in Lattin, which they vnder≈øtood not, this William Mathewes, ≈øeeing how he v≈øed the other two, when as he offered to ble≈ø≈øe him, thru≈øt away his hands, and tolde him, that his ble≈ø≈øing was rather a cur≈ø≈øe, (to them that beleeued it was of anye force) then a ble≈ø≈øing: Which wordes vnder≈øtoode by an Engli≈øh Frier, appointed to be theyr interpreter, and reuealed vnto others ≈øtanding by.

The ≈øayde Mathewes was greeuou≈øly buffeted, in the Cardinals pre≈øence, whereat he ≈øeemed to be very di≈øcontent. Well after ≈øome outragious wordes offered to Mathewes for refu≈øing this Holy Fathers ble≈ø≈øing. The Cardinall began againe to worke ≈øuch meanes and per≈øwa≈øions as he he≈øt could, to drawe them vnto his will, prote≈øting that hee was ≈øuch a fauourer of their cau≈øes, that hee was greeued to ≈øee or heere of their mi≈øerye: yet (quoth hee) I haue intreated tho≈øe Holy Fathers. Seniors of the Church of Rome, cheefe≈øt in commi≈ø≈øion for his Holine≈ø≈øe, to mittigate the extremitie of the lawes, for the puni≈øhment of Heretikes prouided, ≈øo that yee will bee reformed, and become Catholikes, and liue like Chri≈øtians, for≈øaking your damnable opinions, which vnle≈ø≈øe you doo, you cannot be ≈øaued. (It may be) quoth this Holy Cardinall, that your de≈øire to liue in your Countrie with your freends, maye cau≈øe you ≈øtande vpon more pointes then willinglye you would. If that be the cau≈øe ≈øtande not one ≈øuch tearmes, for on mine honour you ≈øhall haue ≈øufficient maintenance out of the Kings
trea≈øurye. Be ruled, and you ≈øhall liue in ≈øo good „Äà‚óä„Äâ with vs, as the be≈øt men in England. You haue heard how the Catholike Princes, haue ioyned their forces to abate the pride of your Countrie, and to make them know the liuing God, for which entended voyage our proui≈øion is all ready, and knowing by reportes of ≈øuch Matriners whome in ≈øecret I haue ≈øente to conferre with you, that you are men of ≈øufficiencie, to take the charge of good ‚Ä¢ hippes, for that you are borne in that damned Countrey, I haue thought good to make you offers of fauoure ≈øuch as your owne Countrie ≈øhall neuer afforde mell ‚Ä¶ ≈øimple birthe.

Fir≈øt from your impri≈øonment you ≈øhall be „Äà‚óä„Äâ , next ≈øhall you be conducted to all places where our forces are, where euery of you ≈øhall make choi≈øe of what „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ llya≈ø≈øe, Pinnis, or other, you will ≈øerue in as Mai≈øter: where „Äà‚óä„Äâ dooing your true entents, like faithfull Souldiers of the liuing God, and his Catholike Churche of Rome. And God ≈øhall giue tho≈øe mi≈øcreants into your handes, whereof there is no doubt, you ≈øhall be there aduan≈øed to what honours you will require, and 500. Duckets monthly to be paide you of the King, if you thinke well of this my offer, let me ≈øee your willingne≈ø≈øe to confirme my reque≈øt.

Tho≈øe faithfull ≈øeruants of God, who≈øe comfort is the great God of I≈øraell, hauing hearkened vnto the alluring ≈øpeeches of the Cardinall, as meanes to pull them from the trueth calling to minde howe Chri≈øt him≈øelfe was tempted of the Deuill by worldly promotions, Iob tryed and per≈øecuted, yet remayned con≈øtant in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, took ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ on that God which comforteth the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, who feeling the fle≈øhe weake and willing, hardeneth theyr heartes again≈øt their offers, and the Popi≈øhe Doctrine preached vnto them. And Mathewes in the name of the re≈øt „Äà‚óä„Äâ aun≈øwered.

Your grace hath ≈øaid ≈øufficient in mine opinion, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ your ‚Ä¶ e≈øt Catholick from his allegiance, both from Antechri≈øt whom you ≈øerue, and the Kings ≈øeruice: yet ≈øhall your grace know, we are Engli≈øhmen, who not ob≈øtinatly refu≈øe your gracious offers, but in that they are offered to the ende „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øhoulde fall from GOD, for≈øaking the true doctrine of Chri≈øt, to cleaue to your damnable opinions: from good ≈øub
‚Ä¶ , you woulde drawe vs like Rebels, to beare Armes again≈øt our Countrey where we receiued life, ≈øeeking to ≈øhed the blood of Chri≈øtians, (a damnable ra≈øe) bereauing our own bloodes with the Enemies ≈øword, by whom we were nouri≈øhed, thereby to heape the vengeance of God vpon vs. No, no, my Lord, (quoth he) rather then it ≈øhall be ≈øaide that an Engli≈øh man ≈øhall deliuer his Countrey into the hands of the deuill, (for no better I account you, nor none of your Religion, who≈øe mindes be butcherlike, delighting in nothing but „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ) let me die, and my bretheren with me, or inflickt ≈øuch puni≈øhments on vs as you plea≈øe, that God, which deliuered Deuell from the Lyons, the three innocent children from the burning Ouen, and many other wonders hath ≈øhewed for his „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øhall deliuer vs from your tiraunie, or giue vs the like patience to endure it.

The Cardinall hearing his offers ≈øo reiected, was gr√©eued not a little, wherefore he commaunded them away to pry≈øon, whether going, they were by ≈øuch as heard theyr aun≈øweres, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and abu≈øed, as it might gr√©eue a man to think on it. Thys purpo≈øe fayling, the Cardinall tooke order that they were ≈øent vnto the Duke of Sauoy, to ≈øerue in hys Gallyes, where two of them remained euer ≈øince, vntill Chri≈øtmas „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ there came from Sauoy a power of men, with Munition and victuals, to goe for Brittaine as it is ≈øuppo≈øed, in which Fleete came tho≈øe two which were left liuing, namelie, Iohn Hari≈øon and William Matthewes, who on the xxiiij. day of Ianuary, (after theyr computation) were ≈øent for againe before the Inqui≈øition, and in like manner as before with great fauours offered libertie, if now they would ≈øerue,
and larger offers then before.

But Matthewes in the name of the other and for him≈øelfe, aun≈øwered, that nece≈ø≈øitie could not draw him from the ioyes of heauen, to liue in plea≈øure on the earth, and therefore per≈øwaded them, that they ≈øhoulde no more vrge him vnto it; for it was friuolous, and rather then he would hold vp his hand, or giue the lea≈øt worde of adui≈øe to preiudice his Prince and Countrey, he would willingly yeeld to what torment ≈øoeuer.

The States of Holly-hou≈øe demaunded of Hari≈øon, if his minde were ≈øo re≈øolute as that damned. Here ‚Ä¢ ique his companion? Who aun≈øwered, in no damnable opinions he wold be ruled by him, but if hee remained in tho≈øe opinions which he did profe≈ø≈øe, he would confirme with his blood what Matthewes had ≈øpoken. When they ≈øawe that no per≈øwa≈øions might auaile them, nor mi≈øery which gr√©euou≈øly they had endured, mooue them to for≈øake theyr true God, they were coÃÑ mitted againe to pry≈øon, and the Prelates called a coun≈øell what to doo with them, who hauing debated thereon ≈øufficiently, determined to burne them to the en≈øample of others.

The next day they were againe called before them, when after ≈øome ≈øp√©eches v≈øed in like manner: to winne them from theyr opinion, and that it woulde not preuaile, with rayling ≈øp√©ech they recounted vnto them, how fauourably it had plea≈øed the Cardinall to deale with them, and to ≈øpare their liues, willing that they ≈øhoulde liue: but ≈øince nothing might preuaile, they were now eyther to receiue theyr former „Äà‚óä„Äâ , or to prepare them≈øelues to die.
The≈øe ≈øp√©eches could not terrifie them, but as men de≈øirous for Chri≈øt and his truth, to bee freed from the torment which they endured, craued no fauour, but wi≈øhed them to proceede.

figure.head: The Iudge giuing ≈øentence of death again≈øt them.

div.p: Theyr aun≈øwere giuen, Don Fredericke chiefe≈øt in the Comi≈ø≈øion ≈øtoode vppe, and as he was pronouncing the ≈øentence of death again≈øt tho≈øe innocents, a ≈øuddaine feare fell vpon them all that were pre≈øent, and Don Fredericke was ≈øtriken dumbe, that hys tongue foltering in his mouth, hee could not ≈øpeake a word. Thys ≈øtrooke a terror in them all.

Don Frederick b√©eing carried away, Don Franci≈øco chiefe Ambnere to the Cardinall ≈øtoode vp, & rayling again≈øt tho≈øe pooremen, told them, that they wrought by ≈øorcery & witchcraft, calling them deuils, and v≈øing other bad ≈øp√©eches, forgetting God was of power, to ≈øhowe his might in puni≈øhing tho≈øe mi≈øcreants, vpon whom it plea≈øed him to ≈øhew the like example, by taking from him, not onely the v≈øe of his tongue, wherewith he abu≈øed tho≈øe ≈øeruants of GOD, but al≈øo his lymbes, to the great admiration of the company, ≈øo that hee was carried away likewi≈øe from the iudgement place.

Then fell the people generally to rayling on them, and with gr√©euous ≈øtrokes to lay vpon them, ≈øo that if GOD had not mooued one of the State to pittie them, they had b√©en pre≈øently ≈ølaine among≈øt them. From thence they were againe committed to pry≈øon, where they endured all the extremities po≈ø≈øible for men to abide, whom God for his mercies ≈øake ≈øtrengthen, and relea≈øe at his plea≈øure.

Within two dayes following, another example worth the noting happened. There were ryding in the Harbour certaine Hulkes, to the number of 26. ≈øayles, ≈øome of Lubicke, ≈øome other of Au≈øterdame, and of other places of the Ea≈øt Countries, into which harbour al≈øo came two ≈ømall Barkes of S. Mallowes in Fraunce, loden with Corne for proui≈øion of the Kings Fleete, which is expected to come for Brittaine. Tho≈øe two French ≈øhips, hauing mored them≈øelues a ≈øtarne a Hulke of Au≈øterdame called the Fortune, chaunced to haue her Anckors come home, and thwarted the Frenchman ≈øo, that it put him in ≈øome daunger, that betwixt them grew ≈øome hote ≈øpeeches. The next day the Frenchman are≈øted the Hulke for his damage, and accu≈øed vnto the Inqui≈øition ≈øixe of tho≈øe Hulkes, that theyr traffique was for Engli≈øhmen, and that the goods were all Engli≈øhmens, wherevpon they were ≈øtayed to the Kings v≈øe, and theyr men impri≈øoned, which the Duchmen denied, as iu≈øtly they might. But the Frenchman on his oath auerred the ≈øame, ≈øo that there was no remedie but to loo≈øe theyr goods and endanger
them≈øelues. Yet God who ≈ø√©eth the ≈øecrets of all mens harts, and canat hys plea≈øure lay them open to the world, to ≈øhewe hys wonders on earth & make his name more feared, ≈øhewed thys mo≈øt gracious and wonderfull miracle, within 6. dayes after the conuiction of tho≈øe Flemmings.

The Frenchman hauing taken order for vnloding of their Corn ‚Ä¢ , as the Mai≈øter of the Barke which accu≈øed them, was bu≈øted with his companions, a ≈øuddain Lightning with gr√©euous weather happened, in which ≈øtorme, a Thunder≈øtone as it is ≈øuppo≈øed, ≈ølew the Mai≈øter, who had before fer≈øworne him≈øelfe, da≈øhing his braynes about the ≈øhyp, and fired both the Shyps of Corne, which could not be quenched by all the meanes they coulde make, nor ≈øaue one penniworth of the ≈øame, to the great wonder of all the beholders.

After which example, the Flemings ≈øuing by their friends for theyr libertie, cau≈øed certaine of the companie on theyr oathes to be examined, touching the accu≈øation giuen by the Mai≈øter of the Barke again≈øt them, who affirmed before the Cardinall, that the Mai≈øter had confe≈øt among≈øt them diuers times, that he did it but for reuenge, and would often reioyce in the mi≈øery of the men, who by his meanes were in danger both of goods and life. Vpon who≈øe reports they were all di≈øcharged, and theyr goods deliuered, but not without great charge and hinderaunce.

Thus gentle Reader, haue you heard the works of God, in reuenging hys ≈øeruants on tho≈øe of authoritie, who oppre≈ø≈øed them, which lye ≈øtill in mo≈øt pittifull manner, without remedie, albeit they haue not wanted for the coun≈øels of the approoued≈øt Phi≈øitions in the whole Land. But God, is iu≈øt, and will be knowne, I pray God thys example prooue of ≈øufficient force, to turne their deuili≈øh mindes to the knowledge of the true God, who defendeth hys children, and will puni≈øh tho≈øe ≈øtifnecked mi≈øcreants that di≈øhonour his name.

In thys Pamphlet al≈øo may≈øt thou ≈ø√©e the reward of periurie, and the iu≈øt iudgement of God, in bereauing hys lyfe,
that ≈øought the liues and de≈øtruction of tho≈øe hee had neuer ≈ø√©ene, for a ≈ømall offence by ca≈øualtie committed, for which they offered him large amendes which might not ≈øuffi≈øe, as al≈øo if Gods iudgements might be coniectured by men, howe God was angry, in releeuing tho≈øe which ≈ø√©eke to di≈øhonour his Name, with that Corne which would haue doone good among≈øt that famous King of Fraunce his Campe where it is needed, yet purloyned by tho≈øe Rebels of his own Countrey, to maintaine his enemies. God make euery man to amende his owne faultes, and to feare, that God will inflict the lyke plague vpon our Countrimen, that for gaine rob the Common wealth of victuals, and maintaine the Enemies of God and our Country. God giue euery man grace to forbeare ≈øo de≈øirous a minde of couetou≈ønes, and make vs thankfull for all his benefits, which thorow his mercies we daily receiue. Amen.
